content.description: What's My Line climbs more like a Smith route than a typical Flagstone slabfest.  After a slabby section at the bottom, the route turns vertical with small but solid crimps and a few underclings.  You may find yourself weaving left and right across the bolt line a few times.  The crux comes between the last two bolts, reaching for a distant pocket with the feet in a wide stem.
content.protection: 7 bolts, two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Two bolt lines to the right of Morning Desire (which can be identified by its homemade angle iron hangers).

content.description: This is a fun route with a wide variety of holds.  Climb High Noon or Morning Desire to a small ledge with two sets of belay bolts (optional belay, the climb can be done in one pitch if desired).  From this ledge, Walt's Wall goes straight up through a section of undercling flakes, then moves up and right on pockets and edges.  It finishes at a two-bolt anchor just over a small bulge.
content.protection: Bolts, two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
Climb High Noon or Morning Desire to reach a ledge halfway up the wall.  Walt's Wall starts from here (see beta photo on the Walt's Wall area page). 

  Rappel once (one 60m rope just barely reaches the ground), or walk off to the right.

content.description: This varied route starts with a thin slab, then moves up and left through a slightly overhanging section with underclings, pinches, mantles...a bit of everything.  The crux is near the top, climbing past a thin flake.  After pulling a small bulge, you can either clip the anchors on the route just to the left (Beguiled) or continue up and right (about 30 feet of 5.6 slab) to another anchor.
content.protection: Bolts, two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: On the right hand side of Walt's Wall, near a large stump.  One rope rappel.

content.description: Climb slabby 5.8-ish terrain and continue straight up when a line of bolts (Afternoon Delight, 5.8) forks off to the right.  When the rock steepens near the top, the crux comes on solid edges to the right of the bolt line.
content.protection: Bolts, two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: On the left side of Walt's Wall, just to the right of Paradicey.

content.description:
Climb a low angled slab to a short 5.9 section.  Finish on 10a edges.   

  I find that the bottom section cruises.  You'll know when you're at the first crux (5.9) when it gets steeper.  Perform the one move wonder to get past this section and cruise up to a ledge.  Ponder your sequence briefly and grab onto some solid (10a) edges.  A small mantle finishes it up.   

  For whatever reason, the lower "crux" seems harder to me, but I think it is more heady than hard.
content.location: Farthest left route on Walts Wall; or just right of the Hydrotube area (past the arete).

content.description: Another slabby climb using friction and edges.  The crux comes near the top, as the route heads left to the same ledge that High Noon finishes on.
content.protection: Bolts, two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Just to the right of High Noon (see beta photo on the Walt's Wall area page).  Look for a line of bolts with homemade angle iron hangers.

climbs.name: High Noon
climbs.fa: David Tvedt, Dee Tvedt and Allan Kelly, 2002

content.description: A slabby climb using friction and edges.  Climb up and left until you reach a shallow left-facing dihedral.  Climb easier ground in the dihedral to a small ledge with two sets of belay bolts.
content.protection: Bolts, two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: The route starts on the left side of Walt's Wall, just uphill of a stump (see beta photo on the Walt's Wall area page).  Look for a line of bolts that curves up and left.

content.description: A thin start brings you to ledges then the Harp. A good place to shake out. Continue up, keeping center and left of the bolts makes route finding easier as you pull the bulge (crux). There are chains directly up about 10 feet back. Or you could keep going right , its a little dirty. Very Fun for the grade!
content.protection: Bolts to the fixed anchors, about 10 draws?
content.location: Walk uphill from hydro tube, after the dark water mark look for the harp shaped block about midway up. First bolt is near a stump.

content.description: A tricky start past the first three bolts, gives  way to easier climbing.
content.location: The route on to the furthest right on Walts Wall.

content.description: Short balency crux between the 2nd and 3rd bolts.

This route starts with a very thin but well-protected slab crux before ascending up and slightly right into a faint water groove with a fun mix of technical and powerful movement. If you enjoyed Harp of Stone, this is worth a try. Bring your dancing shoes.
content.location: Just right of Harp of Stone, look for a line of bolts ascending a subtle, dark-colored scoop.

content.description: This route shares the 5.6 dihedral finish with High Noon, but provides a noticably harder start, and will feel hard for the grade. If you are not solid at the grade, a stick clip is probably not a bad idea. For people for whom this is their limit, toproping this with a directional or two after leading High Noon might not be a terrible idea.
content.location: Just right of Solar Evening, this route shares a finish with High Noon, which is the next route to the right.

content.description: The wall to the right of hydro-tube.
